supportDesc.support: All medieval leaves parchment. Paper endleaves.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos by multiple hands, and including a number of corrections, including by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

supportDesc.collation:
A composite manuscript consisting of a larger Part of 159 leaves (itself apparently comprising two codicological units), and two leaves from another manuscript at the end of the volume:
Quire 112 (ff. 1-12)
Quire 212-1 (11th leaf missing, stub visible; ff. 13-23)
Quires 3-412 (ff. 24-47) ;
Quire 58 (ff. 48-55)
Quire 610 (ff. 56-65)
Quires 7-128 (ff. 66-113)
Quires 13-1512 (ff. 114-149)
Quire 1610 (ff. 150-159) |
Two leaves (ff. 160-161)
112 212-1 (11th leaf missing, stub visible) 3-412; 58 610 7-128 13-1512 1610 | two leaves
No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
Quires are numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. Quires are marked with a small + in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto in the second half of each quire. No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: 17th-century binding. Rebacked and extensively repaired in the 20th century by the Gray bindery; Gray stamp visible on the turn in above the left pastedown. Covers are sprinkled calf over paste or mill board with matching decoration in blind to each cover. Covers are decorated with a narrow double-fillet at the perimeter of the boards and a dotted single-fillet inset from the perimeter of the boards by c. 20mm. Small fleurons at each corner of the dotted-fillet frame, positioned between the dotted-fillet frame and the double-fillet frame. Head, fore and tail edges of the covers decorated with a double-fillet.

Spine is green-brown leather. Five raised bands with double-fillet decoration at the upper and lower perimeter of each compartment and at the upper and lower openings of the spine. Spine is capped at head and tail: head and tail bands are not visible. A title 'ALCHEMICA' tooled in gold on the spine in one compartment and 'Ii.3.17' for the current shelfmark tooled in gold in another.

Paper pastedowns pasted over the turn ins. The right pastedown is blank. The left pastedown contains:
A former CUL shelfmark of the 'Greek letter type' in ink: #.H.η.16
A title for the volume in ink: 'Rosarium Medicum'
A former catalogue number for the volume in ink: 280
The current shelfmark in ink: Ii.3.17
A record in Latin of the donation of the volume by John Rant of Gonville and Caius in 1655
A Cambridge University Library bookplate
A 'D' in pencil - the size-based classification system used for manuscripts in Cambridge University Library
Four paper flyleaves (watermark of a vase with flowers) at each end of the volume (ff. [i]-[iv] and [v]-[viii] probably contemporary with this binding.
Binding height: 295 mm, width: 200 mm, depth: 45 mm.

Small puncture at the centre of ff. 160-161, the perimeter of the hole stained green. This damage is typically caused by brass (or other copper-alloy) book furniture such as a staple, boss, or fastening plate. There are no metal features on the present binding and as the damage appears on leaves that would probably not have been endleaves in their original legal manuscript context, it is likely that a previous binding for the entire composite volume included a metal fitting in the centre of the back board.

provenance.p: ?Ownership inscription of a Wylhemus Chausey Chausey, William in a 15th or 16th century hand: 'Ego Wylhelmus Chausey publicus' (f. 161r).
?Ownership inscription of a William Martyn Martyn, William in 15th- or 16th-century hand: 'Ego Wylhelmus Martyn publicus' (f. 162r).

history.acquisition: Given by John RantRant, John a fellow of Gonville and Caius College in 1655. There is a record of the donation in ink on the left pastedown: 'Ex dono ornatissimi simul et doctissimi viri Johannis Rant olim Collegii Gon. & Caii socii dignissimi 1655'. Although Gonville and Caius has had several members with the name John Rant, only one of them seems to have been a Fellow of the College at the right time to make this donation, see Venn:ACAD RNT626J.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on: A. Timmermann, 'Alchemy in Cambridge: an annotated catalogue of alchemical texts and illustrations in Cambridge repositories',Nuncius: Journal of the Material and Visual History of Science 30:2 (2015) 345-511 at pp. 493-96 D. W. Singer, Latin Alchemical MSS, 3 vols (Brussels 1928-1931) An unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74)

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: Number '280' in the continuation to the Ecloga of Thomas James compiled c. 1672 and now MS Oo.7.59. This number is recorded on the left pastedown.
H.η.16 in the 'Greek letter' classmark system in use at Cambridge University Library prior to the introduction of the 'Two Letter' classmark system. This shelfmark is recorded on the left pastedown.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.3.17, ff. 1-47, 48-159

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes and charms

incipit.unclear: Ad oseruandum pomacum durem aserum sine putrefaccione . Recipe heminam seminis mustardi terre bene et distempera cum aceto

msItem.explicit: 30v et ad omne iudicium uerum et probatum ut dixit et affirmabat super animam suam ille qui docuit me qui vocabatur magister P. de Florentia.
msItem.note: Collection of chemical, alchemical and medical recipes and charms added by multiple contemporary hands. Ff. 1r-2v barely legible. Entries numbered in the the margins, and a list of numbered entry titles (nos. 15-204) added to the outer or lower margins of ff. 3r-28r.

msItem.title: Extracts from Turba Philosophorum
msItem.author: Magister Panton
msItem.rubric: 30rLiber magri panton
msItem.incipit: 30r In nomine domini amen. Liber de turba philosophorum quem extraxhit magister panton’. Incipio tractare de eo quod uidi meis oculis
msItem.explicit: 30v ita quod vitrum fit malleabile sicut aliud metallum et fit per annum.

msItem.title: Alchemical excerpts and notes
msItem.incipit: 30v Ad bonum solem Accipe limature calibis
msItem.explicit: 34r Aqua tingebat peroptime cuprum ablutum.

msItem.title: Experimentum
msItem.author: Frater Philippus, OP
msItem.rubric: 34r Nota hoc capitulum de limatura ferri et de olio ouorum
msItem.incipit: 34r Accipe limaturam ferri perfecte ablutam
msItem.explicit: 35v usque ad infinitum mittat M. vel lunam bonam. Explicit

msItem.title: De coloribus
msItem.incipit: 35v De perlis. Sumes perlas et terreas subtiliter
msItem.explicit: 37r si sit in aprili bis sena retro redibus.

msItem.title: Liber de tincturis telarum et coriorum
msItem.rubric: 37r Liber de tincturis telarum et coriorum
msItem.incipit: 37r Primo ad inde cum sume de succo ebulorum pondera .x.
msItem.explicit: 37v cum aceto similiter et in mercura rati cum aqua denigrat totum.

msItem.title: Charm for freeing a prisoner
msItem.rubric: 37v Ut homo incarceratus statim liberatur
msItem.incipit: 37v Si quis est in carcere dicat hoc . Sicut sanctus ferribus fuit liberatus
msItem.explicit: et tantum de dicta meua quantum de aliis.

msItem.title: Experimentum
msItem.incipit: 37v Experimentum magistri Petri de Vercellis contra wlnera fistulas

msItem.title: Alchemical excerpts and notes
msItem.rubric: 37v Ad faciendum oleum vitreatum
msItem.incipit: 37v Tere salem cum quo volueris olei
msItem.explicit: 38v ad deconquendum cum galla.

msItem.title: Panacea (recipes)
msItem.incipit: 38v Sacias [pro: Facias] de festuca nodata in fronte infirmi
msItem.explicit: 38v et postea tercia dimitte et liberabitur.

msItem.title: Historia Karoli Magni et Rotholandi (excerpt)
msItem.author: Pseudo-Turpin
msItem.incipit: Rolandus interpretatur heres misericordie ... Karulus interpretatur lux carnis ... Turpinus interpretatur pulcherimus
msItem.rubric: 38v Nota hunc processum de Rege Karolo
msItem.incipit: 38v De persona et fortitudine karoli Et erat rex carolus capillis brunis
msItem.explicit: 38v super palmam suam a terra usque ad capud suum sola manu velociter eleuabat.
msItem.note: Excerpt from ch. 20.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.note: Four alchemical recipes, including:

msItem.rubric: 39r Modus faciendi Risalgar
msItem.incipit: 39r Rialgar est dragra(?) vitriol
msItem.explicit: 39r alaluthell es rialgar.
msItem.note: Preceded by two other alchemical recipes, not mentioned by Singer.

msItem.title: Collection of Dicta Philosophorum
msItem.incipit: 39r Dicit Hermes in libro secretorum corpora soluta
msItem.explicit: 41r quod non fugit ab igne.
msItem.note: Cites Hermes, Diascorides, Aristotilis, Nicholaus, Tullius, Frater Philippus de ordine predicatorum, Socrates, Avicenna, Gallenus, Arturus, Asser sive Assenfilius, Belenus, Johannis de Anglia, Maurenus

msItem.title: Panacea (recipes)
msItem.incipit: 41r Ad morsum serpentcis accipe terram sub pede dextro
msItem.explicit: 41r ad tingendum rubeum.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.rubric: 41r Nota hic de anaxatir
msItem.incipit: 41r Anoxatir figens et tingens accipe anoxatir
msItem.explicit: 41v et ferminus ea in ipsa.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes (Preparatio sulphuris)
msItem.rubric: 41v Incipit liber magistri Berardi . hanc preparacionem sulphuris misit magister erardo speciali amico suo
msItem.incipit: 41v Cum uolueris facere capitum fortissimum Recipe
msItem.explicit: 42v et tamen meliora id si potes et deus te munet in illo amen

msItem.title: Story
msItem.incipit: 42v Narratio hahabalhabar philosophi hahabalhabar quidem sapiens
msItem.explicit: 42v funde iterum et fiet luem alba rubiusdissima.

msItem.title: De coloribus
msItem.incipit: 42v Omnem tincturam rubeam proba
msItem.explicit: 43r et sic faceres usque fierit medicina currens. Quid sit tinctum forte fieret frangibile proice eam ubi dictum est.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.rubric: 43r Modus preparandi arsenicum
msItem.incipit: 43r Preparatio arsenici cum exungia
msItem.explicit: 43v et erit sol optimus deo volente.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.author: Theodoric
msItem.rubric: 44r Opus Theodorici
msItem.incipit: 44r Hic incipit opus magistri Theodorici qui ait istud est opus facilius et ueracius quod ego inueni perambulando constantinopolim greciam tum et marrocum
msItem.explicit: 46v Lapidis maioris et capillis sed ego non posui ... propter hoc quod non habeam.
msItem.note: The text begins with a short prologue on f. 44r.
The following Item is in a different hand, but it may be a continuation of this text by a different scribe.
There is a short prologue on f. 44r, followed by some alchemical recipes. The first alchemical recipe on f. 44r begins: 'Recipe calcis unam partem et de ydrogiros 3 partes

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.incipit: 46v Recipe Saturni 2 lib. et semis quem funde
msItem.explicit: 47v et docuit testimonium perhibet veritati. Explicit et bene.
msItem.note: This Item is possibly a continuation of the previous item in another hand.

msItem.title: Planetary and alchemical table with symbols
msItem.note: Followed by a note in the lower margin added in a small hand: 'Dicendum est de proiectione post absolucionem cum peruentus fuit ...'

msItem.title: ? Rosarius ?
msItem.rubric: 48r Rosarius
msItem.incipit: 48r Aaccipe ossa turbidi maris et mitte in aquam
msItem.explicit: 51v et tercio quousque ad prescripti operis optatum finem peruenias faciendum
msItem.note: Also in Wolfenbüttel, Herzog August Library, Cod. Guelf. 433 Helmst. 284r-284v, and Leiden, UB, Voss. chyme F 1, 127r-127v.
Singer (1928) Corr. 113.vi proposes that this Item and the next may be parts of the same text.

msItem.title: ? Lumen luminum magnum ?
msItem.author: Rhazes (attrib.)
msItem.rubric: 52r Liber Rasis expositionis elementorum
msItem.incipit: 52r Liber etiam exposiscionis elementorum continet
msItem.explicit: 59v Hic profecto disciplina comite paupertate lares proprios inhabitare recusat. Finit. Amen.
msItem.note: Singer (1928) Corr. 113.vi proposes that this Item and the previous may be parts of the same text.

msItem.title: Liber de compositione alchemiae (excerpt)
msItem.author: Morienus Romanus
msItem.rubric: 59v Incipit interrogaciones regis Khalid et responciones morieni de omnibus in quibus tota efficatia magistri Hermetis constare probatur.
msItem.incipit: 59v Moriene primum querere libet quod et qualis sit huius rei principat
msItem.explicit: 68v totum in etheheb purissimum conuertetur. Sit ergo benedictus deus per cuncta seculorum secula amen
msItem.finalRubric: 68v Explicit liber elkemie de arabico in latinum translatus erat millesima centesima octogesima secunda in mense februarii et in eius die undesimo in hora octava eiusdem diei etc.
msItem.note: The explicit contains a dating clause which records that the translation into Latin was completed 'millesima centesima octogesima secunda in mense februarii et in eius die undesimo in hora octava eiusdem diei', i.e., at the 8th hour of the 11th of February 1182.
This is the translation attributed to Robert of Chester Robertus Castrensis . Another copy of the text with a similar explicit is Oxford, Bodleian Libraries, MS Digby 162, f. 23r)

msItem.title: Alchemical text
msItem.incipit: 68v Pernet lumere de spaine Gumme blaunche e gumme ruge ille gumme
msItem.explicit: 69vet ens reseuent mye le gouvernail de la verite pre lor ignoraunce
msItem.note: This appears to be a translation of the 'Alumen de Hispania'.

After the explicit, there are 6 lines of verse in Latin, typically found as the concluding lines of Latin versions of this text: 'Maria mira sonat hic breuiter talia donat ... Gaudet in assata Sociata per tria sata' (See Singer (1928) 790, 817; Timmerman, 'Prose Texts', esp. p. 311; and cf. eTK 0849C).

listBibl.bibl: A. Timmermann, 'Prose Texts' in Verse and Transmutation: A Corpus of Middle English Alchemical Poetry Critical Editions and Studies (Brill, 2013) pp. 305–326

msItem.title: Alchemical and other(?) receipes
msItem.note: Added by different but contemporary hands.

msItem.title: De perfecto magisterio
msItem.incipit: 70r QVoniam solis indagine vniuersarum rerum artificia
msItem.explicit: 87r et ultima non possum
msItem.note: Medieval copies of this text are often attributed to Aristotle or Abū Bakr al-Rāzī.

msItem.title: Alchemical receipes
msItem.incipit: 87r Sciendum quod attramenta multa sunt. Et ego nisi illum eligo quod est viridis
msItem.explicit: 87v ut per se ad aerem resoluatur et erit oleum

msItem.title: Commentary on the Lumen luminum
msItem.rubric: 87v Incipit liber qui dicitur lumen Luminum . ex libris medicorum et experimentis philosophorum collectis
msItem.incipit: 88r Alumen multis modis est ac diuersorum colorum
msItem.explicit: 94r rubeus ut sanguis tingit mirabiliter
msItem.note: A text with a very similar incipit is in Bologna, University Library, MS 138 (104), ff. 310v-315v.

Some of the minor sections of text in this Item closely resemble passages of text found in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 6514, ff. 41v-53r , some of which is printed in J. Corbett, Catalogue des Manuscrits Alchemiques Latins (Bruxelles, 1939), pp. 294-309. In particular, see the alchemical preparations described in the lower half of CUL MS Ii.3.17, ff. 92r, and Corbett, p. 300, Recettes 7-9 (et seq.). See also eTK 0265J and 1535L for other possible identifications of parts of this Item.

msItem.title: Alchemical recipe to make aurichalcum (orichalcum)
msItem.rubric: 94r Ad faciendi latonem
msItem.incipit: 94r Recipe tuchiam pulverizatam
msItem.explicit: 94r et postea fundatur et ...
msItem.note: In a different hand from the preceding text.

msItem.title: Epistola ad Hasen regem de tecta
msItem.author: ps.-Avicenna
msItem.rubric: 94v Epistola Auicenne Ad Asam de re tecta
msItem.incipit: 94v Hec pertracta sunt inter me auicenne et ason quod de eo quod ipse verba que rogauit
msItem.explicit: 99v non est ignis et citrinum completur quatuor
msItem.note: See https://www.mirabileweb.it/title/epistola-ad-hasen-regem-de-re-recta-title/127222.

msItem.title: Commentary to Epistola ad Hasen regem
msItem.rubric: 99v Incipit exposicio super eandem epistolam
msItem.incipit: 99v Interrogacioni vestre de secretis nature respondens vobis scribo
msItem.explicit: 101v apud omnem artem et scientiam naturalem

msItem.title: Alchemical text
msItem.incipit: 102r SCcitote quod septem sunt planete vnde sol uocatur Aurvm, Luna Argentum
msItem.explicit: 102v omnium philosphorum est separare purum ab impuro Explicit

msItem.title: Alchemical texts
msItem.incipit: 102v Quatuor sunt elementa et unumquidque illorum potest redigi
msItem.explicit: 110v et sulphur sunt elementum id est materia et principium omnium liquebilium et metallorum. Hec omnia dicuntur in libro metheororum Explicit

msItem.title: Alphabetical list of alchemical substances
msItem.incipit: 110v Argentum vivum aurum vivum aqua
msItem.explicit: 111r zegi id est vitriolum

msItem.title: Commentary on the Liber rebis of Mercher ad Fledium
msItem.incipit: 114r Cvm omnis philosophia siue scientia inutilis et vana censeatur
msItem.explicit: 118v cum sanguine hircino
msItem.note: See Timmermann (2015) for list of subtitles.

msItem.title: Sermo de aluminibus et salibus and recipes
msItem.author: ps.-Rasis
msItem.rubric: 118v Sermo de aluminibus et salibus et attramentis et aliis quem hac arte necessaria existium ad complementum elixir. Sermo de attramento
msItem.incipit: 118v Scias quod attramentorum genera sunt multa et eius minere sunt multe et ipsum quidem est aqua
msItem.explicit: 131v-132rConuersio auri in argentum ... ergo est aqua et tinctura
msItem.note: See Timmermann (2015) for list of subtitles. Singer (1928) 28.v and Corr. 28.v does not recognise as separate text.

msItem.title: Mercher ad Fledium, Liber rebis (fragment)
Liber Dabessi
Liber Hermetis de alchimia
msItem.author: Mercher
msItem.rubric: 132v Hic incipit liber lapidi rebis merelini
msItem.incipit: 132v Dixit merebis ad fledium Serua quod tibi dicam et scribe. Sume de lapide rebis
msItem.explicit: 133v quoniam ipse est iusticia
msItem.finalRubric: 133v Expletus est liber de Roberto deo gracias
msItem.note: See also CUL MS Add. 4087.

msItem.title: Liber solis et lune
msItem.author: ps.-Hermes
msItem.rubric: 133v Incipit liber solis et lune scilicet Hermetem in lapide dahessi
msItem.incipit: 133v Qvoniam de opere in quo philosophorum doctorum doctissi
msItem.explicit: 140r fac tincturam de azorio rubificato
msItem.note:
It is not clear if this is one text or several combined texts. Other possible incipits:
135v: DIxit ieberbenhayen Sal est radix huius operis
139r: IN lxx'a quinque ponitur venus pro cupro quinque stagnum de preparacione secundum morienum

msItem.title: Liber administrationum
msItem.incipit: 140v Ut ait alkindus hic disciplina quibusdam possessionis detrimentum infert
msItem.finalRubric: 141v quarta limature indice idem conflabis permiscebis auripigmento rubeo exures teres et era
msItem.note: Attributed to Kindī, -approximately 873Kindī in the manuscript.
See Mirabile.

msItem.title: Liber triginta verborum
msItem.author: ps. Geber
msItem.rubric: 141v Incipit liber de xxx verbis
msItem.incipit: 141v Iam scis tu qui hanc queris doctrinam nos hanc rem multis modis explanasse
msItem.explicit: 144r proice vnam ex illis super mille quod facias donec tuus compleatur numerus
msItem.note: Followed by one paragraph:

msItem.incipit: 144r Cementum quod semel siccatum
msItem.explicit: 144r aliquantulum facias bullire

msItem.title: Liber de naturis colorum
msItem.author: ps.-Aristotle
msItem.rubric: 144r Incipit liber de naturis colorum iuxta aristoteles septuadecima preceptorum
msItem.incipit: 144r Notato quoniam ignis solus aurum conculcat siue interimit Acetum quoque es ipsam interimit et in viridem
msItem.explicit: 145r Ouorum namque magna est utilitas et multiplex nam et sapientes puluerem combustionem in eis idem consistere affirmant qui ex eodem fomento quoddam sepius sunt experti

msItem.title: Liber duodecim aquis
Preface to the Liber duodecim aquarum
msItem.rubric: 145r Incipit liber duodecim aquarum Capitulum primum
msItem.incipit: 145r Libelli hujus aquarum series duodecim splendet capitulis

msItem.title: Liber duodecim aquis
msItem.incipit: 145r Ovorum uitella equale teres et in medulle speciem redigeratur totum
msItem.explicit: 152r et in simul recipiet colorem aureum

msItem.note: See http://www.mirabileweb.it/title/de-duodecim-aquis-title/167204

msItem.title: Liber coniunctionum
msItem.author: Kindī
msItem.rubric: 152r Incipit liber coniunctionum liber scecundus algium
msItem.incipit: 152r Ex antiquorum scententia philosophorum precepit esse colorum genus ex mineria principale
msItem.explicit: 154r 4 milia in solem transmutat

msItem.title: Alchemical excerpts and notes
msItem.rubric: 154r De litera cuprea uel enea uel aurea ualde pulcra
msItem.incipit: 154r Tere cuprum intote duro donec denascetur et puluerem habeas sufficientem
msItem.explicit: 157v partem i auri addideris fiet aurum optimum
msItem.note: At least items, some 5 without titles.

msItem.title: Alchemical text
msItem.rubric: 157v De vij planetis e de vij metals issi aperut la manere
msItem.incipit: 157v Ki vout sauer le art e la mestrie
msItem.explicit: 159v si la sublimat si com ies vous ay dist'
msItem.note: Another hand added rubric in the upper margin: "De preparacionibus metallorum". Final leaf ends with catchwords "devant L a primere"

supportDesc.collation:
This Part of the manuscript consists of 159 leaves apparently comprising two codicological units (ff. 1-47 and ff. 48-159):
Quire 112 (ff. 1-12)
Quire 212-1 (ff. 13-23: 11th leaf missing, stub visible)
Quires 3-412 (ff. 24-47)
Quire 58 (ff. 48-55)
Quire 610 (ff. 56-65)
Quires 7-128 (ff. 66-113)
Quires 13-1512 (ff. 114-149)
Quire 1610 (ff. 150-159)
Sequence of Roman numeral leaf signatures in red ink visible in the lower outer corner of some of the rectos in the first half of Quires 2 and 4. Occasional medieval leaf signatures in Hindu-Arabic numerals in light brown ink in the upper outer corner of ff. 1-49.
Another sequence of medieval leaf signatures visible in the lower outer corner of some of the rectos in the first halves of Quires 8-10; Quire 8 has partial 'b' signatures, and Quires 9 and 10 have clear 'c' and 'd' signatures, so this particular sequence probably began with a set of 'a' signatures in Quire 7 (now presumably lost to trimming).
No quire signatures particular to this Part. Catchwords on ff. 12v, 23v, 35v, 55v, 65v, 73v, 81v, 89v, 97v, 104v, 125v, 137v, 149v, 159v.
supportDesc.condition: The volume has been conserved and the quires have been taken down and remounted with paper guard strips visible between each quire. Some leaves badly rubbed and stained, and some text now illegible.

layout.seg: Frame and line ruling in plummet, faintly up to f. 47 and more strongly thereafter, bounding lines extended to the edge of the leaf. Ruled in single-column format, 29-38 lines to the page, written below top line. No pricking visible.

handNote.p: Written by several scribes, in Anglicana up to f. 46v, and Anglicana formata from f. 48r onwards (and for additions to ff. 46v-47v). An enlarged style of Anglicana formata is used as a display script for rubrics and chapter headings from f. 48r onward.

decoNote.p: Red and blue initials and pilcrows.

Alchemical marginal sketches:
20r distilling apparatus
24r ‘locus ignis’
47v table of alchemical symbols
113v circular diagram of planetary system

origin.origDate: Written between the mid-14th and mid-15th centuries.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.3.17, ff. 160-161

msItem.title: Digest (Fragment: Liber 45.1.45.1 - 45.1.118)
msItem.author: Justinian
msItem.incipit: 160r stipulari possunt . Si ita quis stipulatus sit
msItem.explicit: 161v stipulanti mihi promittit . prope est ut omnimodo sit utile . quamvis

listBibl.bibl: T. Mommsen, P. Krueger Corpus Iuris Civilis I (Berlin, 1954)

msItem.title: Alchemical note
msItem.incipit: 160v Accipe metalla
msItem.explicit: 160v et albo copyrpose
msItem.note: In the lower margin, in a different hand to the main text.

physDesc.p: 161r161r: mit obligationes aut omnino non differt

extent.seg: Fragment - two contiguous leaves from a medieval legal manuscript reused as endleaves in a later medieval volume.

supportDesc.collation:
Two contiguous leaves from a medieval legal manuscript.
No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part. No catchwords particular to this Part.
supportDesc.condition: Two contiguous leaves from a medieval legal manuscript reused as endleaves in a later medieval manuscript. The lower portion of f. 160 (approximately 105x155 mm (height x width)) has been cropped away. The leaves have been stabilised and areas of damage on the leaves have been patch-repaired by conservators at an unknown date. The leaves have been trimmed for reuse as endleaves and text has been lost along the top edge of the leaf.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in two-column format, trimmed along the top edge of the leaf with text lost, but 37-38 lines of text visible in each column. Pricking marks visible along lower edge of leaves.

handNote.p: The main text is written in a northern textualis libraria of the 13th century.

decoNote.p: Outline sketches in the lower margins of f. 160r and f. 161r in faint leadpoint or crayon of a man's head in profile wearing a coif.
Flourished initials at divisions of the text; plain red or blue initials with the other colour used for small flourishes that extend only slightly into the adjacent margin.
Plain initials in red or blue at minor divisions of the text.

decoDesc.decoNote: Occasional paraph marks in red or blue.

binding.p: Small puncture at the centre of ff. 160-161, the perimeter of the hole stained green. This damage is typically caused by brass (or other copper-alloy) book furniture such as a staple, boss, or fastening plate. There are no metal features on the present binding, but as the damage appears on leaves that would probably not have been endleaves in their original legal manuscript form, it is probable that the previous binding to the composite volume included a metal fitting in the centre of the back board.

origin.origDate: First half of the thirteenth century

revisionDesc.change: Tuija Ainonen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library and Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
